revision:
1. If a natural number \(m\) can be expressed as \(n^2\), where \(n\) is also a natural number, then \(m\) is a square number. In other words, a natural number \(m\) is a perfect square if it is equal to the product of a number with itself. These numbers are also called perfect squares.
  2. Properties of Square Numbers :
    • If a number has \(1\) or \(9\) in the unit's place, then it's square ends in \(1\).
    • When a square number ends in \(6\), the number whose square it is, will have either \(4\) or \(6\) in the unit's place.
    • If a number has \(2\) or \(8\) in the unit's place, then it's square ends in \(4\).
    • If a number has \(3\) or \(7\) in the unit's place, then it's square ends in \(9\).
    • A number ending in \(2, 3, 7\) or \(8\) is never a perfect square.
    • Squares of even numbers are always even and squares of odd numbers are always odd.
    • \(2n\) non-perfect square numbers exist between the squares of the numbers \(n\) and \((n+1)\)
    • The sum of first \(n\) odd natural numbers is \(n^2\)
  3. We can express the square of any odd natural number as a sum of two consecutive integers.
  4. For any natural number \(m>1\); \(2m, (m^2-1)\) and \((m^2+1)\) is a pythagorean triplet.
  5. The square root of a given natural number \(n\) is that number which when multiplied by itself gives \(n\) as the product and we denote the square root of \(n\) by \(\sqrt{n}\). Thus, \(\sqrt{n}=m \Rightarrow n=m^2\). Square root is the inverse operation of square.
  6. In order to find the square root of a perfect square, resolve it into prime factors; make pairs of similar factors and take the product of prime factors, choosing one out of every pair.
